questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the cognitive revolution in psychology?

options.A: A shift from studying observable behavior to studying mental processes
options.B: The invention of brain imaging technology
options.C: The discovery that all learning is based on reinforcement

questions.misconception_description: The cognitive revolution was triggered by brain imaging technology rather than a theoretical shift in focus from behaviorism to mental processes.

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of working memory?

options.A: To store information permanently for later retrieval
options.B: To temporarily hold and manipulate information during cognitive tasks
options.C: To automatically process sensory information without attention

questions.misconception_description: Working memory is the same as with long-term memory, believing working memory is for permanent storage rather than temporary active processing.

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of working memory?

options.A: To store information permanently for later retrieval
options.B: To temporarily hold and manipulate information during cognitive tasks
options.C: To automatically process sensory information without attention

questions.misconception_description: The agent confuses working memory with long-term memory, believing working memory is for permanent storage rather than temporary active processing.

questions.question_text: Which example best demonstrates automatic processing?

options.A: Learning a new phone number by repeating it
options.B: Reading words fluently after years of practice
options.C: Solving a complex math problem step by step
options.D: Trying to remember what you ate for breakfast

questions.misconception_description: The agent thinks retrieval from memory is always automatic, failing to distinguish between effortful recall and truly automatic processes that occur without attention.
